div.a: 2. Character Dialogue in The Hound of the Baskervilles
3. Distinctive Narrative Voices in The Moonstone and As I Lay Dying
4. Less Distinctive Character Parts: The Coquette, The Power of Sympathy, The Ambassadors, Jane Eyre, and The Sun Also Rises

div.div: Department of English, New York University, USA
Search for other works by this author on:
Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_2, December 2017, Pages ii17–ii30, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqx022

div.p: David L Hoover, The microanalysis of style variation, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_2, December 2017, Pages ii17–ii30, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqx022

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: Computational stylistics has often analyzed variations in the style of a single author or text, including chronological change, the dialogue or narration of multiple characters or narrators in a single novel, and other perceived shifts in style. Here, I examine intra-textual style variation from a different perspective, and suggest circumstances under which it is appropriate and beneficial to omit some parts of texts from an analysis to eliminate sources of predictable and intrusive variation that would render other kinds of variation or consistency of style invisible. In other cases it may be appropriate to randomize a text to mask a kind of variation that would otherwise disrupt an analysis. One way to do this is by sorting the lines of the text in random order before analyzing it in sections. In analyses in which texts of very different lengths must be compared, it is also beneficial to randomize the longer parts, cut them all to approximately the length of the shortest one, and use the equalized amounts of text to create a word frequency list that is not biased in favor of the longer parts. These techniques can lead to a deeper understanding of style variation.

div.p: Style variation comes in a myriad of forms and has a wide variety of causes. Authorship and genre obviously affect texts, as do historical period, register, theme, and subject matter. Many of these variations across collections of texts have been the subject of computational studies that are sometimes termed ‘distant reading’, ‘text mining’, or ‘macroanalysis’ (Jockers, 2013). On a smaller scale, which I call ‘microanalysis’, computational stylistics has often focused on style variation within a single work or author as a way of better understanding authorship and style. Studies of variations in authorial style can focus on factors as diverse as personal relationships, literary influences, significant life experiences, variations in subject matter, the time period in which the text is set, point of view, or setting. Authors’ thematic interests may also cause variations in their styles, as may the genres and sub-genres in which they work, and intentional stylistic departures are especially interesting to the student of style. Chronological change has also been a significant focus, and many analysts assume that change in an author’s style over time is either universal or the norm, given a career of significant length (Craig, 1999; Juola, 2006; Hoover, 2007; Stamou, 2008). Other chronological studies consider the general effects of aging, or the effects of Alzheimer’s and other diseases (Garrard et al., 2005; Le et al., 2011).

Style variation sometimes, however, seems to threaten the validity of the entire enterprise of authorship attribution and computational stylistics. As Burrows and Craig (2012) have noted, critics like Masten (1997) and McMullan (1996) have argued that the separation of drama into the voices of multiple characters makes authorship attribution of drama problematic. Yet, Burrows and Craig show that the various characters in plays can be very successfully grouped by author. It may even seem that the ability of some authors to create distinctive voices for multiple narrators, letter authors in epistolary novels, or characters in novels, or to create intentional stylistic variations of other kinds, threatens the very notion of authorial style. This problem is more apparent than real, however, because the presence of substyles within an author’s style is quite compatible with an overall distinctiveness that distinguishes that author from others. Mr Darcy can be distinct from Elizabeth Bennett in Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice without threatening the distinction between Austen and other authors (Burrows, 1987; McKenna and Antonia, 1996; Hoover, 2003, 2016).

Analysts have sometimes, however, felt it advisable to limit or mask some kinds of variation. It is clearly best, where possible, to limit texts in an authorship attribution or stylistic study to those of similar genre, date, register, and even length and theme, to prevent these other factors from influencing the results. On a smaller scale and in different contexts, it is often advisable to limit an analysis to dialogue or narrative only (Burrows, 1992; Hoover, 2014), or to analyze character parts in drama, dialogue in fiction, or letters in epistolary novels by addressee as well as speaker (Hoover et al., 2014). Another widespread practice, analyzing only function words, rests on the powerful a priori arguments that authors are unlikely to manipulate the frequencies of function words and that content words are too likely to vary by context. In spite of the plausibility of this argument, including many more of the most frequent words (MFW) almost invariably improves results. Nevertheless, I have introduced the practice of ‘culling’ these longer word lists to remove words that are among the most frequent because of a high frequency in a single text (Hoover, 2003), and others have used another kind of culling to limit the words to be analyzed to those that appear in all or most of the texts (Jockers et al., 2008; Eder et al., 2016).

Analysts have also sometimes removed personal pronouns because they are so strongly influenced by the genders of the main characters (Binongo and Smith, 1999; Hoover, 2003). Burrows combines several authorial samples into a single primary authorial sample in his introduction of his Delta authorship measure (2002); this practice ‘averages out’ some of the intra-authorial variation, and produces a fairer measure of the author’s overall style than any single text would provide. Recently, I have been using several texts by each author as primary samples to reduce the potential problems of variation in authorial style and to provide information about which of the author’s primary samples is most like the texts to be attributed.

As with inter-textual variation, there are many reasons for intra-textual variation, and many of them overlap in complex ways. An important secondary character may appear in only part of a novel, for example, so that his or her dialogue may be distinctive partly because of the limited setting. If a character also interacts only with one other character, then the limitation of addressee may also have an effect. At the same time, such a character may also have an unusual plot function that affects the dialogue, as might the character’s race, gender, ethnicity, social class, and so forth, and authors often highlight—or exaggerate—these characteristics by altering their dialogue. Other aspects of characterization, such as age, personal and family history, regional dialect, moral or religious beliefs, and so forth, are also often reflected in a character’s dialogue. Computational analysis of intra-textual style variation seems absolutely crucial to our understanding of this complex state of affairs. We can begin the necessary investigation by considering some circumstances in which it is advisable to omit parts of texts, or to randomize a text or part of it to mask some variation, or to truncate (randomized) texts or parts of texts to create a word list based on equal amounts of text by various characters or narrators (Burrows, 1992; Hoover, 2016).
div.h2: 2. Character Dialogue in The Hound of the Baskervilles
div.p:
Franco Moretti has argued that ‘Doyle owes his phenomenal success to his greater skill in the handling of clues’ (2004: 48), but Holmes and Watson are also extraordinarily memorable and fascinating characters. As no less a critic than Eliot (2015: 605) puts it:
And every critic of The Novel who has a theory about the reality of characters in fiction, would do well to consider Holmes. There is no rich humanity, no deep and cunning psychology and knowledge of the human heart about him; he is obviously a formula. He has not the reality of any great character of Dickens or Thackeray or George Eliot or Meredith or Hardy; or Jane Austen or the Brontës or Virginia Woolf or James Joyce: yet, as I suggested, he is just as real to us as Falstaff or the Wellers. If part of the success of the stories is a result of effective characterization, is it reasonable to expect Doyle to have created distinctive voices for Holmes and Watson as a way of characterizing them? What may be a more significant question—whether memorable characters are normally characterized by distinctive dialogue styles—depends at least partly on the answer to questions like this. Analyzing the voices of Holmes and Watson for distinctiveness requires comparing them with Doyle’s other characters, and, because reliable results require substantial amounts of text, I focus here on the longest Holmes novel, The Hound of the Baskervilles (1901-02; Hound, below).

After all the dialogue of the six characters who speak more than 1,500 words in Hound was extracted, each character’s dialogue was combined into a separate document for analysis.1 The dialogue was analyzed in sections of about 1,500 words to prevent the wide range in the lengths of the parts from skewing the results and to allow the consistency of each character’s part to be tested more adequately. Initial cluster analyses based on the 200 MFW show that sections of the dialogue cluster by character except for two sections of Holmes’s dialogue and one of Sir Henry Baskerville’s; analyses using fewer or more words are somewhat less coherent. These failures cast doubt on the distinctiveness of these character parts (Fig. 1).2 Both failures, however, seem likely to result from intra-textual style variation that probably should not influence the analysis. Henry Baskerville’s problematic section is largely a conversation with his servant Barrymore, with whose section it clusters. Perhaps the topic and setting cause the two voices to merge and their sections to cluster. Barrymore’s entire part is only about 1,500 words, however, so Doyle may not have been attempting to make it distinctive. In his classic early study of Jane Austen, Burrows considers only those characters with parts of about 2,000 words to be ‘major’ ones, worthy of analysis (1987), and it seems reasonable to expect authors to make a greater effort to create distinctive voices for major characters than for minor ones. The contrary trend—with minor characters being strong caricatures with oddly distributed vocabularies—is also found (Burrows, 1987: 48), but Barrymore seems an unlikely example of this. In any case, the lack of a distinctive Barrymore style would not adequately explain the clustering of a section of Baskerville’s dialogue with Barrymore’s.

img.alt: Character parts in Hound (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

div.p: Character parts in Hound (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

img.alt: Character parts in Hound (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

div.p: Character parts in Hound (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

One way to test whether an otherwise consistent Baskerville style has been disrupted by a local variation is to sort the lines of his dialogue in random order before dividing it into sections. The text could be more thoroughly randomized, but sorting by line has the benefit of leaving the text sections at least marginally comprehensible and retaining some of the influence of syntactic structure. With Baskerville’s dialogue randomly sorted and then divided into three equal sections, the randomized sections cluster separately from Barrymore’s dialogue, which forms its own cluster. (For characters with single sections, randomization has no effect because the entire text is being analyzed at once; similarly, analyzing whole novels averages out differences among character voices and between narration and dialogue, producing a composite picture of authorial style.)

Analyzing just the dialogue of Barrymore and Baskerville, in sections of only about 750 words, with both randomized, gives fascinating results, with completely correct clustering from the 25–200 MFW (in 25-word increments). These results suggest that randomization to dampen the effects of local variations may be a valuable tool for the study of intra-textual style variation. Some important questions remain, however. If some voices are not very distinctive, for example, will randomization always allow even their weak distinctiveness to cause sections of them to group together separately from other voices, or will they sometimes tend to cluster with other weakly distinctive randomized parts? How consistent should a character’s dialogue be across different settings, through plot changes, over time, and when addressing different characters? Do most or many or few authors have the ability—or the desire—to make their characters sound different from each other? Examining some additional test cases of various kinds will begin to suggest answers to such questions, but it is important to remember that style variation questions are fundamentally different from authorship attribution questions. In the latter, we have known cases to use for training, but it is difficult to justify treating some cases of style variation as ‘known’. And simply assuming that all authors create distinctive voices for their characters or narrators seems quite dubious (see Hoover, 2003 for more discussion).

Holmes’s two outlier sections come from and account for almost all of the long final chapter of the novel, ‘A Retrospection’, which is Holmes’s explanation of elements of the case that were unknown to Watson. Holmes is ostensibly ‘speaking’ this chapter to Watson, but it is much more like narration than dialogue, and Watson interrupts briefly only three times in the entire chapter. This genre difference seems the most likely reason that these sections cluster separately from Holmes’s otherwise strongly consistent sections. Special pleading in the face of apparent failure may seem illegitimate, but in this case, evidence can be brought to bear concerning the similarity between these retrospective sections and narration. T-tests on the 1,000 MFW of the dialogue and narrative of Thomas Hardy’s A Laodicean (1881) and Henry James’s The Ambassadors (1903) identify words with statistically significant differences in frequency in dialogue and narrative without allowing Hound to influence the list of words.3 (The choice of novels was a matter of convenience; these are two novels I had divided into narrative and dialogue for other projects.) More than 400 of the 1,000 MFW test significantly different at the P < 0.01 level, which means that there is less than 1% chance that the differences in their frequencies between dialogue and narrative could arise by chance. The twenty most distinctive markers for dialogue and narration (P < 0.0001) are the following (mostly function words):
Dialogue: I, you, are, is, can, me, will, think, have, we, my, well, not, has, yes, know, say, do, shall, it
Narration: the, was, had, his, of, which, in, on, seemed, from, by, he, its, were, himself, and, eyes, face, with, appeared The first- and second-person pronouns, present tense verbs, and modals of the dialogue contrast nicely with the third-person pronouns, past tense verbs, and prepositions of the narrative (see Biber, 1988 on the characteristic differences between speech and writing). A total of 388 of the 400 statistically significant dialogue and narrative markers identified in James and Hardy appear in the dialogue and narrative of Hound. A cluster analysis (not shown here) of these words in Holmes’s true dialogue; his retrospective ‘dialogue’; his dialogue from three other stories; Watson’s narration, diaries, and letters; the legend of the ‘Curse of the Baskervilles’; and a newspaper report about Sir Charles Baskerville’s death places the retrospective dialogue with the other narratives and separates it widely from his other dialogue, as well as clustering all the dialogue together. (The stories, taken from The Return of Sherlock Holmes, were originally published in 1903–04, just after Hound.) Indeed, even the ten most distinctive markers produce this same clustering. These analyses confirm the narrative nature of the final chapter of Hound and fully justify treating it differently.

Removing Holmes’s retrospective account from the analysis and returning to a normal word list consistently clusters the remaining sections of his dialogue together and clearly separates them from the dialogue of the other characters.4 Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 2, Holmes’s dialogue from other stories again clusters well with his normal dialogue from Hound in an analysis based on the 200 MFW. There is a single error for Stapleton, whose dialogue clusters with Holmes’s (Stapleton, the villain of the novel, has the second shortest part of those analyzed, at about 1,800 words). Analyses based on the 150 and 175 MFW are similar; because of the shortness of these sections, smaller numbers of words outperform larger numbers. Normally, in an analysis of several novels by a single author, sections of each novel strongly tend to cluster together, however, so it is not clear whether we should expect a repeating character’s dialogue from multiple texts to group together consistently across them. Not enough character dialogue has been analyzed to allow any firm generalizations, but here inter-textual consistency supports an intra-textual argument about the distinctiveness of Holmes’s style. Finally, randomizing all the parts long enough to supply two or more sections of 1,500 words produces analyses (not shown here) with perfect clustering by character, based on the 200–500 MFW (100-word increments) . The fact that repeating this analysis, but including all of Holmes’s dialogue randomized, produces perfect clustering based on the 200–400 MFW (100-word increments) reinforces the idea that these techniques should be used judiciously.

img.alt: Character parts in Hound, and three other stories (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

div.p: Character parts in Hound, and three other stories (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

img.alt: Character parts in Hound, and three other stories (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

div.p: Character parts in Hound, and three other stories (200 MFW; ca. 1,500 word sections)

div.h2: 3. Distinctive Narrative Voices in The Moonstone and As I Lay Dying
div.p: Consider next the seven main narrators in Wilkie Collins’s The Moonstone (1868) (see Hoover et al., 2014 for a more general discussion and a different method of dealing with style variation). Collins explicitly motivates his multiple narrators by having Franklin Blake ask those characters who are most familiar with parts of the story to narrate those parts. He also creates quite varied narrators: an old male family servant, a female servant with a police record, a poor and hypocritical religious relative, a famous detective, the family lawyer, a young nobleman, and a disgraced but sympathetic mixed-race doctor. Under these circumstances, it seems reasonable to expect the narrators to sound different from each other, and Collins does an excellent job overall of distinguishing them (all dialogue was removed from the sections to avoid contaminating the narrative voices). In the most accurate clustering I could achieve (shown in Fig. 3), there is only one error, clustering the second part of Blake’s narrative with the third section of Jennings’s (which, incidentally, it immediately follows). Here, randomizing all of the parts of at least 3,000 words (with longer sections split into blocks of about 3,500 words) greatly improves accuracy, correctly clustering all sections by all narrators in analyses based on the 100–1,000 MFW (100-word increments).

img.alt: Seven narrators in The Moonstone (800 MFW, complete linkage, 3,500 word sections)

div.p: Seven narrators in The Moonstone (800 MFW, complete linkage, 3,500 word sections)

img.alt: Seven narrators in The Moonstone (800 MFW, complete linkage, 3,500 word sections)

div.p: Seven narrators in The Moonstone (800 MFW, complete linkage, 3,500 word sections)

William Faulkner seemingly faces a more difficult task in As I Lay Dying (1930). Not only is the novel set in the (fictional) small, mainly rural and isolated Yoknapatawpha County, Mississippi, five of the seven main narrators are members of the Bundren family. The other two are their neighbors, Vernon and Cora Tull. In spite of this restricted setting and the family relationship of most of the narrators, normal analysis of Faulkner’s narrators clusters Darl’s, Vardaman’s, and Dewey Dell’s sections correctly (sections of approximately 2,000 words; pure narration), and the only clear error is that all of Tull’s sections cluster with Cash’s section over a wide range of analyses (Hoover, 2010). Randomizing each character’s narrative correctly clusters the sections of all the characters from the 100–1,000 MFW (100-word increments), and succeeds very well even when all the character parts are divided into sections of about 1,000 words.
div.h2: 4. Less Distinctive Character Parts: The Coquette, The Power of Sympathy, The Ambassadors, Jane Eyre, and The Sun Also Rises
div.p: An examination of less distinct character parts may help to answer one of the questions posed above. If an author has created character voices that are neither consistent nor very distinct, will randomization smooth out the variations and produce speciously ‘correct' results? Randomization only slightly improves the poor separation of the eight largest sets of letters in Hannah Webster Foster’s The Coquette (1797) and the seven largest sets of letters in William Hill Brown’s The Power of Sympathy (1789), showing that randomization does not always produce artificial consistency. (The letters of some characters were divided on the basis of addressee, on the assumption that the difference in addressee is probably not an appropriate variable to suppress.)

Randomization also transforms the poor character separation in standard analyses of Henry James’s The Ambassadors (1903) into a clear separation of all except Little Bilham, in analyses based on the 500–800 MFW (100-word increments). The same is true for Charlotte Brontë’s Jane Eyre (1847), in which the dialogue ranges from Jane’s childhood to her adulthood in five different settings, though it is all filtered through her adult consciousness. Although there is some consistency of clustering with most of Rochester’s dialogue, most of St. John’s, and much of Jane’s, the dialogue fails to cluster either overall, by setting, or by Jane’s age in normal analyses. Randomizing the dialogue, however, produces much better clustering overall and perfect clustering for all six main characters in analyses based on the 500 and 600 MFW.

Jake and Brett from Ernest Hemingway’s The Sun Also Rises (1926) are often mentioned as memorable characters. Although their dialogue clusters better than the four novels just discussed in normal analyses, it does not cluster as well as Collins’s or Faulkner’s narrators or the character dialogue in Hound. The most accurate clustering, shown in Fig. 4, based on the 700 MFW, places Florence’s dialogue in a separate section, and clusters all of Jake’s and Brett’s sections in single clusters, but one section of Bill’s dialogue invades Jake’s cluster and Cohn’s section invades Brett’s cluster; other analyses based on other numbers of words are less coherent. Randomizing the character parts produces the completely correct results shown in Fig. 5 for analyses based on the 400–800 MFW (100-word increments).

img.alt: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—standard analysis, 700 MFW

div.p: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—standard analysis, 700 MFW

img.alt: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—standard analysis, 700 MFW

div.p: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—standard analysis, 700 MFW

img.alt: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—randomized parts, 700 MFW

div.p: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—randomized parts, 700 MFW

img.alt: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—randomized parts, 700 MFW

div.p: Character dialogue in The Sun Also Rises—randomized parts, 700 MFW

These results seem difficult to interpret. It seems promising that the poorly differentiated characters of Foster and Brown are not much affected by randomization, while the clustering of Hemingway’s somewhat more distinct characters is greatly improved. On the other hand, James is not known for his characterization, so that the almost perfect clustering of his character parts over a range of analyses with randomization seems surprising. The same could be said of the great improvement in the clustering of the character parts of Jane Eyre, where, although Charlotte Brontë certainly creates memorable characters, they are filtered through one consciousness and develop over several years and span significant life experiences, varied settings with different minor characters, a substantial change in Jane’s social and economic status, and Rochester’s maiming and blinding. Some further analyses, however, can provide a bit more clarity.

Consider another variation on normal analyses of these books, in which the long parts are randomized and then truncated to roughly the size of the shortest part. A word list based on these roughly equalized parts is then created, so that all of the characters contribute more equally to the set of words that will be used to analyze the whole parts. Using this equalized word list substantially improves the non-randomized analyses for The Ambassadors and Jane Eyre, but creates only minor improvement for The Coquette and The Power of Sympathy. Using equalized word lists along with randomization produces results similar to those using randomization alone for The Ambassadors and Jane Eyre, suggesting that the character parts were more distinct than originally thought. This may have been caused by the dominance of the word list by the dialogue of Strether and Rochester, both of whom speak about half of all the dialogue in each of their novels. For The Coquette, the combination of equalizing the word list and randomizing the character parts does produce improved results for a narrow range of analyses based on fewer than the 200 MFW, though it still fails to cluster all sections of dialogue by two of the characters. For The Power of Sympathy, the minor improvement caused by using an equalized word list and randomization persists over a wider range of analyses, but again never produces complete clustering by character. These results suggest that, in cases where even an equalized word list and randomization fail to produce very good clustering of sections of character dialogue by speaker, the author either did not try to create distinctive character parts or was unsuccessful in doing so.

Randomization is powerful enough that it should be used only when there is a defensible reason to believe that local variations in style may be masking a larger consistency. Consider, for example, what happens when the dialogue of all the characters in Hound is analyzed in five consecutive randomized sections of about 6,000 words—sections that contain varying amounts of dialogue by the various major and minor characters. This kind of smoothing of variation is clearly inappropriate in a study of character dialogue per se, but, perhaps surprisingly, when these five sections are analyzed in blocks of about 2,000 words, there is a great deal of clustering by section. In fact, in analyses based on the 500–1,000 MFW (100-word increments), all three blocks from each of the five sections form single clusters. Apparently the varying proportions of dialogue by different characters create five distinctive artificial composite voices that allow the analysis to distinguish the sections from each other. This is almost certainly augmented by the structure of the novel, as most of the 1,000 words are content words. This suggestion is further supported by the fact that, in all analyses, whenever two of the three-block clusters of sections join together into a larger cluster, all the resulting clusters are consecutive. That is, the three blocks of Sections 3, 4, and 5 first form individual clusters, then the Section-3 and Section-4 clusters join together, and are then joined by the Section-5 cluster.

Bram Stoker’s multivocal Dracula (1897) raises some especially interesting issues that call for a more extended discussion. This novel consists of various characters’ diaries, journals, letters, memoranda, notes, reports, and telegrams, along with news stories and a ship’s log. Randomizing the six narrative parts that are longer than 3,000 words in sections of about 4,500 words of pure narrative gives perfect clustering for the 100–1,000 MFW (100-word increments), though Harker 1 (his journey to Transylvania and work for Dracula) and Harker 2 (his part in the struggle against Dracula in England) cluster separately. A comparison with a standard analysis, however, raises questions about the appropriateness of the homogenization of these narrative parts. As shown in Fig. 6, the standard analysis fails to cluster all the sections correctly. In the middle of the large lower cluster is a problematic mixed cluster containing Van Helsing’s single section and sections by Mina, Harker, and Seward, and this pattern is consistent for the 600–900 MFW (in 100-word increments). If these were unrelated sections by these characters, this analysis would strongly suggest that Stoker had not been very successful in creating distinct styles for his narrators. (The clustering of Lucy’s section with most of Mina’s sections and the clustering of two of Harker 2’s sections with two of Seward’s seem less damaging and will be discussed below.) However, the unusual cluster of four sections by four narrators consists almost entirely of the end of the novel, which describes the race to capture Dracula before he can reach his castle. The close correspondence of plot, setting, and characters for this part of the novel and its rather frenetic pace seem to push these parts of the narratives together, making them more similar to each other than they are to the other sections of each character’s narration.

img.alt: Six Dracula narrators—standard analysis, 900 MFW

div.p: Six Dracula narrators—standard analysis, 900 MFW

img.alt: Six Dracula narrators—standard analysis, 900 MFW

div.p: Six Dracula narrators—standard analysis, 900 MFW

This apparent interplay between the narrators’ styles and narrative structure provides an opportunity to push the question of randomization further and in a new direction. As was true of Jane Eyre and The Ambassadors, the Dracula narratives range widely in length, so that the full word list on which the analyses above are based is skewed sharply away from the word usage of Lucy (4,400 words) and Van Helsing (5,200 words) and toward that of Mina (22,000 words), Harker 1 (19,000 words), Harker 2 (14,000 words), and especially Seward (35,000 words). Combining randomization with truncation, I have produced an equalized word list, as above, based here on the first 6,000 words from the randomized narratives of the four longest parts (taking half from each of Harker’s narratives) and all of the narrative of the shorter parts of Lucy and Van Helsing. The analyses based on this new word list cluster sections of the narrative (approximately 4,500 words each, about the length of Lucy’s part) much more accurately and clearly distinguish the narratives of Lucy and Van Helsing, as can be seen in Fig. 7.

img.alt: Six Dracula narrators—word list based on 6,000 words of randomized parts, 900 MFW

div.p: Six Dracula narrators—word list based on 6,000 words of randomized parts, 900 MFW

img.alt: Six Dracula narrators—word list based on 6,000 words of randomized parts, 900 MFW

div.p: Six Dracula narrators—word list based on 6,000 words of randomized parts, 900 MFW

Harker’s two narratives are more coherent in this analysis, with all sections of both in the large cluster at the top of the dendrogram, but the same widely separated sections of Seward’s narrative that clustered with the first two of Harker 2’s sections before remain clustered with them here. Furthermore, the final sections of the narrative of Harker, Mina, and Seward that clustered consistently in the standard analysis continue to cluster consistently on the basis of an equalized word list. The persistence of these incorrect clusterings even when the contribution of the narrators to the word list has been equalized deserves further investigation. Consider the following rough summary of the 4,500-word sections of Harker 2 and Seward narration:
Seward 1: Chapters 5, 6, 8, and 9 (discussions of Seward’s patient, Renfield, and a letter to Holmwood concerning Lucy)
Seward 2: Chapters 9 and 10(concerning Lucy, transfusions, precautions)
Seward 3: Chapters 11 and 12(concerning Lucy, transfusions, precautions)
Seward 4: Chapters 12–15(concerning Lucy, her death, her empty coffin)
Seward 5: Chapters 15 and 16(concerning Lucy, her destruction)
Harker 2-1: Chapters 14, 17, 19, and 20(tracing Dracula’s caskets, the men search Dracula’s house, Mina bitten, more casket tracing)
Seward 6: Chapters 17–20(He meets the Harkers, the hunt for Dracula begins, Mina bitten, Seward introduces Renfield to the other characters)
Harker 2-2: Chapters 20, 22–23(Renfield’s death, casket tracing, Mina scarred by the Host, the hunt for Dracula)
Seward 7: Chapters 20–23(Renfield attacked by Dracula, he reveals that Dracula is feeding on Mina, his death, Mina forced to drink Dracula’s blood, the hunt for Dracula and his escape)
Seward 8: Chapters 23–27(preparations for chasing Dracula, to the end of the novel)
Harker 2-3: Chapters 23–27(preparations for chasing Dracula, to the end of the novel)

A manual division of these narratives on the basis of narrative structure would make possible a closer examination of the relationship between narrators’ styles and narrative structure, but even the artificial division above is instructive. To investigate further, I analyzed Seward’s Sections 1 and 6 against his Sections 2–5 and 7 in my Wide-Spectrum Spreadsheet (Hoover, 2013 and forthcoming) using a variant of Burrows’s Zeta (2006) that identifies words that are used consistently in one set of texts and avoided in another and vice versa. This kind of analysis works by breaking the two sets of texts into many sections of the same length and then testing every word in the entire word list to see how many sections in each set contain that word (ignoring frequency). The percentage of presence in one set is added to the percentage of absence in the other set to give a distinctiveness score, and the distinctive vocabularies of the two sets are then sorted on this score. I have used Zeta here rather than the t-test because the characteristic words it identifies, while showing considerable overlap with those identified by the t-test, tend to be less frequent and less heavily concentrated on function words, and therefore are more appropriate for investigating the interplay of style and content that is of interest here. The words below are the thirty-five most distinctively used words from Seward 1 and 6 and from Seward 2-5 and 7, in descending distinctiveness score order.5 As my summary above notes, Seward 1 and 6 are heavily influenced by Seward’s discussion of his zoophagous mental patient Renfield, while Seward 2-5 and 7 are heavily influenced by Dracula’s attacks on Lucy and Mina.

Seward 1 and 6 Markers (versus Seward 2-5 and 7):
lunatic, Renfield, man, present, are, anything, manner, has, cause, say, homicidal, new, friend, study, make, attendant, meet, is, thought, men, spiders, wishes, madness, only, know, will, seems, got, flies, reason, satisfied, sane, just, get, to-night Seward 2-5 and 7 Markers (versus Seward 1 and 6):
stood, Arthur, Lucy’s, opened, professor, terrible, lay, lips, death, Helsing’s, over, hand, off, hear, breast, her, Van, Helsing, red, felt, moved, hands, light, white, two, blood, teeth, throat, arm, woman, showed, ghastly, pointed, began, made Further analysis would provide a clearer picture of why the first two sections of Harker 2 group with Seward 1 and 6, but the two lists of the thirty-five most distinctively used words in Seward 1 and 6 and Harker 2: 1 and 2, compared to Seward 2-5 and 7, below, show that fourteen of the most distinctive Seward 1 and 6 markers (in bold) remain among the thirty-five most distinctively used when Harker 2: 1 and 2 are added to Seward 1 and 6, and twenty-four of the Seward 2-5 and 7 markers (in bold) remain among the thirty-five most distinctively used in the new comparison with both Seward and Harker. What this suggests is that the main effect here is caused by the consistent preoccupations of Seward 2-5 and 7, but that Harker 2: 1-2 also shares a substantial overlap with Seward 1 and 6. The coherence of the end of the novel already offers a reasonable explanation for the separate clustering of Seward 8 and the third section of Harker 2.

Seward 1 and 6 and Harker 2: 1 and 2 Markers (versus Seward 2-5 and 7):
new, anything, manner, mina, boxes, Renfield, these, think, carfax, lunatic, house, home, work, got, shall, chapel, man, present, diary, is, find, say, dust, has, few, count, study, able, are, might, know, lord, matter, mr, hope, Seward 2-5 and 7 Markers (versus Seward 1 and 6 and Harker 2: 1 and 2):
Lucy's, professor, Helsing, Lucy, Van, hands, lay, lips, death, Helsing’s, over, moved, hear, opened, light, upon, through, professor's, white, blood, became, teeth, throat, surprise, long, terrible, red, off, began, stood, hand, side, heart, less, pulled As I have noted, Harker’s, Mina’s, and Seward’s final sections remain clustered in Fig. 7. Analyzing these three narrators and Van Helsing’s from the end of the novel (beginning when they leave England to follow Dracula) in shorter sections (about 1,300 words), using a word list based on the equalized randomized parts, is revealing. Seward’s and Van Helsing’s sections cluster separately, as do Mina’s second, third, and fourth section; only her first section clusters with Harker’s. The voices remain relatively distinct, even though they are inflected enough by the effects of the narrative structure, so that they do not cluster with other sections by the same narrators in other parts of the novel. Mina’s wayward section consists mainly of a rather formal memo laying out a method for tracing Dracula, so that its failure to cluster with the sections from her journal also seems explicable. Further analysis of the substyles of Dracula should provide additional insights into intra-textual style variation.

Certainly (intra-)textual variation helps to create memorable styles and memorable characters and narrators, and it is often crucially linked to description, setting, theme, plot, and other textual features. Some kinds of relatively predictable or uninteresting variation, however, can mask important kinds of consistency and unity, so that a reasoned argument can be made for ignoring some sections of texts, or analyzing them in randomized form. Alternatively, or in addition, creating word lists for analysis based on randomized and truncated sections can equalize the effects of the varying language of parts of texts that also vary greatly in length. (A similar effect could be achieved by averaging the frequencies of words over several shorter sections of text.) Many more texts will have to be analyzed to determine why randomization produces varying results and where it is appropriate, but the results of these experiments show that, used judiciously, text-randomization and equalized word lists can reveal overall consistencies that are masked by local effects of style variation without creating specious consistencies in substyles that are not truly distinct. They also show that randomization may cluster parts of texts perfectly by character or narrator even when some of those parts cluster consistently in ways that do not match their characters or narrators in normal analyses. Depending on the purpose of the analysis, such cases of style variation can more profitably be analyzed further, rather than being smoothed away.

The examples discussed here have focused on several different kinds of intra-textual style variation in literary texts, but many other kinds of intra-textual variation remain to be explored. As already noted, the seemingly problematic clustering of randomized dialogue from consecutive sections of novels suggests that randomization may be useful in discovering other kinds of consistencies, for example those based on setting or plot. These techniques have already been shown to produce similarly improved results on a very different kind of non-literary text: the high-stakes writing exams used in many US high schools. In such texts, randomization helps to highlight the differences between low-scoring and high-scoring exams, while reducing the effects of the various genres of writing that varied prompts from many different states elicit (Rybicki et al., 2016). As I have suggested, the related field of authorship attribution has already addressed the problems of intra-textual variation in a number of ways, but it seems likely that the techniques discussed here will also be effective in cases where the texts involved in an authorship attribution problem vary greatly in length or where they are known or expected to exhibit a substantial amount of internal variation and where some kind of sampling from whole texts is required.

1 The process of extracting and separating character dialogue is a tedious and time-consuming one. My Analyze Textual Divisions spreadsheet partly automates the process; it is available online at my Excel Text-Analysis Pages, https://wp.nyu.edu/exceltextanalysis/. See Hoover (2017) for discussion.

2 Cluster analysis is an exploratory statistical method that compares the frequencies of a set of words across a set of texts to determine which texts use those words at the most similar frequencies. Roughly speaking, the further to the left that two or more texts form a cluster, the more similar they are. Unless otherwise indicated, all analyses use Ward linkage and squared Euclidean distance. (Complete linkage, which has also been used in analyses like this, is less effective.)

3 The t-test is a well-known statistical test that assesses the likelihood that a given distribution of a word in two samples could have arisen by chance. The version I am using here, sometimes called Welch’s t-test, is more conservative than the basic Student’s t-test, and is generally preferred for word frequency data because it does not assume equal variances in the two samples. For a discussion of the merits of this and other statistical tests, see Lijffijt et al. (2016). Any basic statistics text will explain the calculation of the test. The most commonly used P value for a result to be considered statistically significant is 0.05, which indicates that there is less than a 5 per cent chance that the distribution could have arisen by chance. The more conservative 0.01 seems appropriate here because there are so many words with highly significant results.
4 I have similarly endorsed ignoring the final ‘summing up’ chapter of The Waves when analyzing its six narrative voices (Hoover, 2016), as have Burrows (1987), Ramsay (2011), and Balossi (2014).

5 I omitted Seward 8 for this test, as it is already known to cluster differently from these sections. The Wide-Spectrum Spreadsheet is available, with instructions, on the Web on my Excel Text-Analysis Pages (Craig and Kinney, 2009; Hoover, 2013 and 2017).
